prompt: Facts: The accused, Bharat Fakira Dhiwar, was married to the deceased, Kamalabai, for about 10 months prior to the incident.; Incident occurred on 11th May 1991, around 6:00 PM in the hut of the accused located in Village Sonewadi, Taluka Kopargaon, District Ahmednagar.; Prosecution alleged that the accused came home drunk and demanded Rs. 10/- from his wife, Kamalabai, to purchase more liquor.; When Kamalabai refused, stating there was no money, the accused allegedly became enraged, poured kerosene from a nearby tin onto her, and set her ablaze with a matchstick.; Kamalabai ran out of the hut screaming, engulfed in flames.; Neighbours, including PW2 Tarabai, PW3 Hausabai, and PW4 Sundarabai, rushed to the spot upon hearing her screams, extinguished the fire, and covered her with a quilt.; Kamalabai was taken to the Rural Hospital, Kopargaon, by PW5 Sampat (brother-in-law of the accused).; A dying declaration (DD1 - Exhibit 28) was recorded by the Special Judicial Magistrate (SJM), PW7 Mr. Bora, at around 10:30 PM on 11.05.1991, after PW1 Dr. Ashok Kumar certified her fit to make a statement. In this declaration, Kamalabai implicated the accused.; Kamalabai allegedly made a second, oral dying declaration (DD2) to her mother, PW6 Manjulabai, on the morning of 12.05.1991, again stating that the accused had set her on fire.; Kamalabai succumbed to her burn injuries (certified as 98% burns by the doctor conducting post-mortem) on 13.05.1991 at 6:15 AM.; The spot panchnama (Exhibit 17) recorded the seizure of a kerosene tin and a matchbox from the accused's hut.; The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Ahmednagar) convicted the accused under Section 302 IPC and sentenced him to life imprisonment.; The High Court of Bombay (Aurangabad Bench) acquitted the accused, citing discrepancies in the dying declarations, lack of corroboration, and suggesting the possibility of accidental fire or suicide.; The State of Maharashtra filed an appeal against the acquittal in the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 300 (Murder definition - relevant clauses likely 'Thirdly' and 'Fourthly')
